traits.smithy.api#documentation:
A trait for specifying what example data looks like. Differs from the `smithy.api#examples` trait in that
it can be used for any shape, not just operations. Below is an explanation of the different example formats
that are supported.
1. SMITHY - this means that the examples will be using the `Document` abstraction and will be specified in
a protocol agnostic way
2. JSON - this means the examples will use the `Document` abstraction, but will not be validated by the smithy
`NodeValidationVisitor` like the first type are. This type can be used to specify protocol specific examples
3. STRING - this is just a string example and anything can be provided inside of the string.
This can be helpful for showing e.g. xml or another encoding that isn't JSON and therefore doesn't fit nicely
 with `Node` semantics

This trait indicates that a String value contains a date without
a time component. Following the RFC-3339 (an extension of ISO 8601),
the default for a date is the following:
date-fullyear   = 4DIGIT
date-month      = 2DIGIT  ; 01-12
date-mday       = 2DIGIT  ; 01-28, 01-29, 01-30, 01-31 based on
                          ; month/year
full-date       = date-fullyear "-" date-month "-" date-mday

See: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3339#section-5.6
e.g.: "2022-03-30"
If a time component is required, you can use smithy.api#Timestamp

Use this trait to give a default value to a structure member. This
is not the same as smithy.api#default which is more constrained.
You can use `defaultValue` to specify a default that does not align
with the target's shape constraints, where as Smithy's `default` trait
prevents that. For example:

```smithy
@length(min:5)
string MyString
structure MyStruct {
  @defaultValue("N/A") // that's valid
  s1: MyString
  s2: MyString = "N/A" // that's invalid
}
```

Retain unknown fields of a containing structure in this member.
In case of unions, retain unknown cases in this member (open unions).
For both discriminated and tagged unions, this retains the entire object.
For untagged unions, having a Document member has the same effect.

smithy.api#trait.selector:
:is(
            structure > member :test(> map > member[id|member=value] > document),
            union:not([trait|alloy#untagged]) > member :test(> document)
        )

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
This trait indicates that a String contains a date-time value without a
timezone component in the ISO-8601 format YYYY-mm-DDTHH:MM:SS[.s{1,9}]
Fractional seconds support a precision up to the nanosecond.

This trait indicates that a String contains a time value without a timezone
component in the ISO-8601 format HH:MM:SS[.ss{1,9}]
Fractional seconds support a precision up to the nanosecond

This trait indicates that a String contains a describint a month and day
in the ISO-8601 format mm-DD
Example: "05-14" reads as May 14th

Use this trait to mark some field as nullable. This is to make
a distinction between an optional field that is missing and one
that's explicitly set to null.

This trait indicates that a Timestamp should retain the time offset
information as defined in RFC3339 Section 5.6.
See: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3339#section-5.6

Must be combined with the @timestampFormat("date-time") trait as only this
format provides offset information.

This trait indicates that a String contains a time value with an offset in
the ISO-8601 format HH:MM:SS[.s{1,9}](+|-)HH:MM
Fractional seconds support a precision up to the nanosecond.

Specifies that an enumeration is open meaning that
it can accept "unknown" values that are not explicitly
specified inside of the smithy enum shape definition.

A rest protocol that deals with JSON payloads only
in HTTP requests and responses. These are encoded with
the content type `application/json`.
See Alloy documentation for more information.
A version of @examples that is not tied to a validator

Unwraps the values of a list, set, or map into the containing
structure/union.
Changes the serialized key of a structure, union, or member.
UUID v4 compliant with [RFC 4122](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4122)
A year in the ISO-8601 format.

This trait indicates that a String contains a value describng a year and
month in the ISO-8601 format.
Example: 2025-05 reads as May of year 2025

This trait indicates that a String contains a timezone identifier such as
America/New_York or an offset from UTC such as +01:00

This trait indicates that a String contains a timezone offset from UTC
such as +01:00

This trait indicates that a String contains a time value with an offset and
a timezone identifier in the ISO-8601 format
YYYY-mm-DDTHH:MM:SS[.s{1,9}](+|-)HH:MM\[ZONEID]
Fractional seconds support a precision up to the nanosecond.

ISO 3166-1 Alpha-2 country code
Full list in https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#search/code/
example: "AF", "US"

Email address as defined in https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2821 and https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2822
A more human-readable format is available here: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3696#section-3

A hex triplet representing a RGB color code
example: "#09C" (short) or "#0099CC" (full)

ISO 639-1 Alpha-2 language code or Language for short.
Column `ISO 639-1` in https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/English_list.php
example: "fr", "en"

BCP 47 Language Tag
IETF RFC: https://tools.ietf.org/search/bcp47
example: "fr-CA", "en-US"

This traits allows the encoding of OpenAPI Extensions
as defined in https://swagger.io/docs/specification/openapi-extensions/.
GRPC protocol as defined by https://grpc.io/

This trait can be used to enable protobuf conversion
on services or structures that are not a part of a
GRPC service.

Specifies how enumeration value should be encodeds in protobuf.
ORDINAL indicates that the enum value should be encoded as an integer.
STRING_VALUE indicates that the enum value should be encoded as the
string value.

This trait can be used to customize the rendering of an
Union shape during the conversion to Protobuf models.
Union in Protobuf are typically encoded using `oneOf`.

`oneOf` can only be used within `message` and each of their
member has an index. This makes them tricky to render.
One possible solution is to create a synthetic `message` to
host the `oneOf`, and then use that `message` FQN at use site
when refering to the Union.
There is an alternate encoding where you render the `oneOf`
inside the `message` where it's used. You can only use this encoding
if the Union is used only inside of one `structure`.

You can use this trait, along with the validator provided, to
implement this encoding.

Specifies which type of number signing should be used on integers
and longs.

Marks certain field indexes as unusable by the smithy
specification. For example, if a range is provided of
1 to 10 then the proto indexes for any fields in that
structure must fall outside of that range. Ranges
are inclusive.

Specifies which type of timestamp representation should be used
PROTOBUF indicates that the default encoding should be used
EPOCH_MILLIS indicates that an int64 should be used instead of the
default encoding.
RFC3339_STRING indicates that the timestamp should be encoded as a string
using the format described in RFC3339 section 5.6.

smithy.api#trait.selector: :test(simpleType, list, map, member > simpleType, member > list, member > map)

traits.smithy.api#documentation: A string representing a service's ARN namespace.
A string representing a CloudFormation service name.
The `/` character.
The `:` character.
The possible delimiters for an ARN resource segment.
Points to an operation designated for a tagging APi

The `tagApi` property is a string value that references a non-instance
or create operation that creates or updates tags on the resource.

The `untagApi` property is a string value that references a non-instance
operation that removes tags on the resource.

The `listTagsApi` property is a string value that references a non-
instance operation which gets the current tags on the resource.
Structure representing the configuration of resource specific tagging APIs

Defines the ARN template. The provided string contains URI-template
style label placeholders that contain the name of one of the identifiers
defined in the `identifiers` property of the resource. These labels can
be substituted at runtime with the actual identifiers of the resource.
Every identifier name of the resource MUST have corresponding label of
the same name. Note that percent-encoding **is not** performed on these
placeholder values; they are to be replaced literally. For relative ARN
templates that have not set `absolute` to `true`, the template string
contains only the resource part of the ARN (for example,
`foo/{MyResourceId}`). Relative ARNs MUST NOT start with "/".

Set to true to indicate that the ARN template contains a fully-formed
ARN that does not need to be merged with the service. This type of ARN
MUST be used when the identifier of a resource is an ARN or is based on
the ARN identifier of a parent resource.

Set to true to specify that the ARN does not contain a region. If not
set, or if set to false, the resolved ARN will contain a placeholder
for the region. This can only be set to true if `absolute` is not set
or is false.

Set to true to specify that the ARN does not contain an account ID. If
not set, or if set to false, the resolved ARN will contain a placeholder
for the customer account ID. This can only be set to true if absolute
is not set or is false.

Defines which character is used to delimit sections of the resource
segment of an ARN. This can only be set if absolute is set to true.

Set to true to indicate that an ARN may be reused for different
instances of a resource.
Specifies an ARN template for the resource.
The AWS CloudFormation resource type contained in the ARN.

An absolute shape ID that references the Smithy resource type contained
in the ARN (e.g., `com.foo#SomeResource`). The targeted resource is not
required to be found in the model, allowing for external shapes to be
referenced without needing to take on an additional dependency. If the
shape is found in the model, it MUST target a resource shape, and the
resource MUST be found within the closure of the referenced service
shape.

The Smithy service absolute shape ID that is referenced by the ARN. The
targeted service is not required to be found in the model, allowing for
external shapes to be referenced without needing to take on an
additional dependency.
Marks a string as containing an ARN.

This field denotes whether or not this operation requires the use of a
specific endpoint. If this field is false, the standard regional
endpoint for a service can handle this request. The client will start
sending requests to the standard regional endpoint while working to
discover a more specific endpoint.

Indicates that the target operation should use the client's endpoint
discovery logic.

Indicates the operation that clients should use to discover endpoints
for the service.

Indicates the error that tells clients that the endpoint they are using
is no longer valid. This error MUST be bound to any operation bound to
the service which is marked with the aws.api#clientDiscoveredEndpoint
trait.
Configures endpoint discovery for the service.

Indicates members of the operation input which should be use to discover
endpoints.
Defines a service, resource, or operation as operating on the control plane.

Customer content means any software (including machine images), data,
text, audio, video or images that customers or any customer end user
transfers to AWS for processing, storage or hosting by AWS services in
connection with the customer’s accounts and any computational results
that customers or any customer end user derive from the foregoing
through their use of AWS services.

Account information means information about customers that customers
provide to AWS in connection with the creation or administration of
customers’ accounts.

Service Attributes means service usage data related to a customer’s
account, such as resource identifiers, metadata tags, security and
access roles, rules, usage policies, permissions, usage statistics,
logging data, and analytics.
Designates metadata tags applied to AWS resources.

Designates security and access roles, rules, usage policies, and
permissions.
Designates the target as containing data of a known classification level.
Defines a service, resource, or operation as operating on the data plane.

The `sdkId` property is a required string value that specifies the AWS
SDK service ID (e.g., "API Gateway"). This value is used for generating
client names in SDKs and for linking between services.

The `arnNamespace` property is a string value that defines the ARN service
namespace of the service (e.g., "apigateway"). This value is used in
ARNs assigned to resources in the service. If not set, this value
defaults to the lowercase name of the service shape.

The `cloudFormationName` property is a string value that specifies the
AWS CloudFormation service name (e.g., `ApiGateway`). When not set,
this value defaults to the name of the service shape. This value is
part of the CloudFormation resource type name that is automatically
assigned to resources in the service (e.g., `AWS::<NAME>::resourceName`).

The `cloudTrailEventSource` property is a string value that defines the
AWS customer-facing eventSource property contained in CloudTrail event
records emitted by the service. If not specified, this value defaults
to the `arnNamespace` plus `.amazonaws.com`.

The `docId` property is a string value that defines the identifier
used to implemention linking between service and SDK documentation for
AWS services. If not specified, this value defaults to the `sdkId` in
lower case plus the service `version` property, separated by dashes.

The `endpointPrefix` property is a string value that identifies which
endpoint in a given region should be used to connect to the service.
For example, most services in the AWS standard partition have endpoints
which follow the format: `{endpointPrefix}.{region}.amazonaws.com`. A
service with the endpoint prefix example in the region us-west-2 might
have the endpoint example.us-west-2.amazonaws.com.

This value is not unique across services and is subject to change.
Therefore, it MUST NOT be used for client naming or for any other
purpose that requires a static, unique identifier. sdkId should be used
for those purposes. Additionally, this value can be used to attempt to
resolve endpoints.

An AWS service is defined using the `aws.api#service` trait. This trait
provides information about the service like the name used to generate AWS
SDK client classes and the namespace used in ARNs.

The `disableDefaultOperations` property is a boolean value that specifies
if the service does not have the standard tag operations supporting all
resources on the service. Default value is `false`

Annotates a service as having tagging on 1 or more resources and associated
APIs to perform CRUD operations on those tags

The `property` property is a string value that identifies which
resource property represents tags for the resource.

Specifies configuration for resource specific tagging APIs if the
resource has them.

Flag indicating if the resource is not able to carry AWS system level.
Used by service principals. Default value is `false`

Indicates a resource supports CRUD operations for tags. Either through
resource lifecycle or instance operations or tagging operations on the
service.

A list of the Amazon Cognito user pool ARNs. Each element is of this
format: `arn:aws:cognito-idp:{region}:{account_id}:userpool/{user_pool_id}`.
Configures an Amazon Cognito User Pools auth scheme.

The signature version 4 service signing name to use in the credential
scope when signing requests. This value SHOULD match the `arnNamespace`
property of the `aws.api#service` trait if present and the `name`
property of the `aws.api#sigv4a` trait if present.

[Signature Version 4](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/signature-version-4.html)
is the process to add authentication information to AWS requests sent by HTTP. For
security, most requests to AWS must be signed with an access key, which consists
of an access key ID and secret access key. These two keys are commonly referred to
as your security credentials.

breakingChanges.message: Removing the existing authentication scheme is not backward compatible and can break existing clients' authentication.

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
The signature version 4a service signing name to use in the credential
scope when signing requests. This value SHOULD match the `arnNamespace`
property of the `aws.api#service` trait if present and the `name`
property of the `aws.api#sigv4` trait.

Signature Version 4 Asymmetric (SigV4A), an extension of Signature Version 4 (SigV4), is the
process to add authentication information to AWS requests sent by HTTP. SigV4A is nearly
identical to SigV4, but also uses public-private keys and asymmetric cryptographic signatures
for every request. Most notably, SigV4A supports signatures for multi-region API requests.

breakingChanges.message: Removing the existing authentication scheme is not backward compatible and can break existing clients' authentication.

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
Indicates that the request payload of a signed request is not to be used
as part of the signature.

Indicates the response body from S3 is not wrapped in the
aws-restxml-protocol operation-level XML node. Intended to only be used by
AWS S3.
CRC64NVME
CRC32C
CRC32
SHA1
SHA256
The priority ordered list of supported HTTP protocol versions.

The priority ordered list of supported HTTP protocol versions that
are required when using event streams with the service. If not set,
this value defaults to the value of the `http` member. Any entry in
`eventStreamHttp` MUST also appear in `http`.
Contains HTTP protocol configuration for HTTP-based protocols.

An RPC-based protocol that sends JSON payloads. This protocol does not use
HTTP binding traits.

An RPC-based protocol that sends JSON payloads. This protocol does not use
HTTP binding traits.

An RPC-based protocol that sends 'POST' requests in the body as
`x-www-form-urlencoded` strings and responses in XML documents. This
protocol does not use HTTP binding traits.

UnsupportedProtocolDocument.message: Document types are not supported with awsQuery

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
Enable backward compatibility when migrating from awsQuery to the awsJson
protocol or Smithy RPC v2 CBOR.
The value used to distinguish this error shape during serialization.
The HTTP response code used on a response containing this error shape.

Provides the value in the 'Code' distinguishing field and HTTP response
code for an operation error.

An RPC-based protocol that sends 'POST' requests in the body as Amazon EC2
formatted `x-www-form-urlencoded` strings and responses in XML documents.
This protocol does not use HTTP binding traits.

UnsupportedProtocolDocument.message: Document types are not supported with ec2Query

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
Indicates the serialized name of a structure member when that structure is
serialized for the input of an EC2 operation.

Defines a top-level operation input member that is used to configure
request checksum behavior.
Indicates an operation requires a checksum in its HTTP request.

Defines a top-level operation input member used to opt-in to response
checksum validation.

Defines the checksum algorithms clients should look for when performing
HTTP response checksum validation.
Indicates that an operation supports checksum validation.

breakingChanges.message: Removing the trait removes the ability for clients to do request or response checksums. The service MUST continue to support old clients by supporting the `httpChecksum` trait.

`requestAlgorithmMember` was removed, so newly generated clients will no longer be able to pick the request checksum algorithms The service MUST continue to support old clients by supporting `requestAlgorithmMember`.

`requestValidationModeMember` was removed, so newly generated clients will no longer validate response checksums. The service MUST continue to support old clients by supporting `requestValidationModeMember`.

Members of `responseAlgorithms` were removed, so newly generated clients will no longer validate response checksums for the removed algorithms. The service MUST continue to support old clients by supporting removed compression algorithms.

traits.smithy.api#documentation: A RESTful protocol that sends JSON in structured payloads.

Disables the serialization wrapping of error properties in an 'Error'
XML element.
A RESTful protocol that sends XML in structured payloads.

UnsupportedProtocolDocument.message: Document types are not supported with restXml

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
Compatibility modes
* none: no compatibility rules are enforced for the annotated shape
* backward: consumers can process data produced by the current and previous
  versions of the shape
* forward: consumers can process data produced by the current and next
  versions of the shape
* full: backward and forward compatible
* frozen: no change can be made to this shape

Select compatibility mode to be enforced on annotated shape
The shape must be annotated with at least one trait describing the
serialization format.

For numbers: lower bound value
For strings and arrays:  minimum length

For numbers: upper bound value
For strings and arrays: maximum length
For string: value must match regular expression
For string: must be an IP v4
For string: must be an IP v6
For string: must be an IP v4 or v6
For string: must be a Url
Provide a list of constaints a field must satisfy for an instance to be valid.

Mark a structure for data lake ingestion.
partitionBy must be set to the path of a timestamp field.
Provide aliases for a specific enumeration value.

When applied to a union the EventUnion trait indicates
that the union regroups several structures annotated with
TypeUrn. The trait will disable checking that all types
in the union namespace are annotated with the TypeUrn trait.

Can be applied to a field or enumeration value to transform the string representation
of the label used when serializing to JSON.

Mark field for masking. The field can either be hashed or redacted.
Only applicable to structure and union members of type string or list of string.

smithy.api#trait.selector: :test(structure, union) > member:test(> string, > list > member > string)

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
Associate a type urn and a schema url values with a model.
These values are required when wrapping an an instance
of the model in an Envelope.

Specify how a protobuf field must be encoded.
Can currently be used on timestamp, datetime and enumeration fields

Assigns an index to a member (structure field, union member, enumeration value).
The index is used during protobuf serialization.
Maintain list of reserver protobuf indices.

Associate a type urn with a model. This trait will
be transformed at a later time into Metadata.
Provide expression used to validate instance of a model.
Version of the registry in which a shape is defined
Allow Avro serialization for annotated shape
Allow DeltaLake serialization for annotated shape
Allow JSON serialization for annotated shape
Allow Protobuf serialization for annotated shape
References a trait

smithy.api#trait.selector: :is(blob, boolean, string, integer, byte, short, long, float, double, bigDecimal, bigInteger, timestamp) :not([trait|trait])

traits.smithy.api#documentation:
Allows for enumeration values to have specific trait for each of its members. The top level
keys of this map are traits (because smithy seem to enforced fqns when shape ids are used
in maps, and fqns are likely to be longer than enumeration values, so we want to reduce repetition).
Trait used to indicate that a member can reuse a reserved name.

Trait used to keep track of names of members that have been removed from a shape.
Reusing a reserved name will cause an error during the model assembly.
Reusing a reserved name can be forced by using the overrideReserved trait.
Adpative Encoding feature used e.g. SQA. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
Unique identifier for the ADK device. This is only applicable for ADK partner devices on NCP.
Correlation ID for each app user session. References mid value in Adobe
Correlation ID for each app user session. References mid value in Adobe
Is it an Advertising or not.
Unique identifier of the specific Deeplink.
Identification of the application. E.g. ESPN+, Disney+ etc.
Application version

Version 3.1 details defined as per version
[3.1](https://searchads.apple.com/advanced/help/measure-results/#attribution-api)

Apple search ads attribution details version 3.1. Defined as per version
[3.1](https://searchads.apple.com/advanced/help/measure-results/#attribution-api)
iad-attribution
iad-org-name

Version 3.1 details defined as per version
[3.1](https://searchads.apple.com/advanced/help/measure-results/#attribution-api)
The ADK version of the running application. This is only applicable for the NCP platform.
Application ID provided to envelope
Application name provided to envelope
Application version provided to envelope
Token returned from an ad service framework to attibute ads to app installs
The AWS region name.
If the error is an SDK error, the enum value of the BAMSDK `ServiceError`.
Indicates if the bluetooth feature was granted for the device
The name of the browser being used to run the applicaiton
The version of the browser being used to run the application

The final capabilities used for playback selection. Used in the request to playlist service to indicate the capabilities of the device at request time. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
List of CDNs attempted and failed. If unavailable or unknown, default to an empty array.
Value increments from 0 for each fallback action. This value initializes at zero for the first CDN attempt, and will increment by 1 for each fallback action that occurs.

The CDN running the server. Default to "null" if not run by a CDN or value is unknown. The SDK pulls cdn name from the "active" playlist. The SDK is expected to substitute a default value for this when one isn't available via the Playlist Response (otherwise, it is a passthrough meaning SDK does not control the name or value).
List of CDNs attempted in case of failure cases. If unavailable or unknown, default to an empty array.

The vendor of the CDN. e.g. VERIZON. Default to "null" if not available. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value. No casing transformation should be applied.

Name of the CDN, appended with Origin e.g. LEVEL3-SECURE. Default to "null" if not available. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
ID representing the linear channel that corresponds to the Element.
The group IDs of the current playback session when testing PQM. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
Indicates if the consent was provided by the fallback (TrustE) or not (OneTrust)
Only present on Web Indicator of CMP consent preferences.  The 5 consent states the user is opted in to.
A comma-delimited string of the specific consent preference identifiers for this user
The unique identifier of the selected content.
The unique identifier of the selected content
The unique identifier of the carousel/set containing the selected content
In MB
Where the media is being played from

Identifier for request used when the view was constructed from search response.
Correlates with search analytics events. The events include content in the same
representation as returned to the client (no additional filtering takes place).
Available CPU in %
The customer support code related to an error. Clients should retrieve this from the sdk for each error logged.

The platformId value on the SDKs is derived from the SDK configs, which is used 
by the Playlist Service to return the plt in Conviva data, which they retrieve from 
the token, which likely receives its value from the device grant metadata.
The following wiki documents how this value is generated across each SDK platform: 
https://wiki.disneystreaming.com/display/SDKC/SDK+Platform+Values+Reporting+Documentation

Data pertaining to an error.

This value will replicate the experiment ID value generated by Optimizely or the feature ID value generated by Weapon X.

This object contains the different variables that are required for experimentKeys when >= 1 experiment is in progress.

Query string of filters returned by playlist service after a fetch request. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
Available Memory in MB
An identifier for the UI view that led the user to this impression. May refer to web URLs, or other identifiers for mobile and device apps. Should always align with adobe page names.

The number of milliseconds it took to fully load the view and present it to the user. The timer starts with intent and ends when all components on the page are full presented (except for lazy loading after scrolling etc.)
Unique Id for a group.
Unique Id type for a group session
The Host of the resource's URL
The HTTP method used for the request.
Represents the status code of the HTTP request
In app purchase location home country. Either ISO3166-1 alpha-2 (2-letter) ISO3166-1 Alpha-3 (3-letter) format.

The three-letter code representing the country associated with the App Store storefront. ISO3166-1 Alpha-3 (3-letter) or ISO3166-1 alpha-2 (2-letter) format. See https://developer.apple.com/documentation/storekit/skstorefront/3182435-countrycode for additional details.

What is the placement of the Deeplink origin

appIcon - App Icon
contentRow - Dedicated row of content
contentTitle - Placement for a single content title/series
epg - Electronic programming guide
partnerMarketing - Partner Marketing related placement
remoteButton - Dedicated remote button
universalSearch - Universal Search result

Type of the placement details of the Deeplink origin (Use Cases)

appOOBE - Out of Box Experience placement
appPreLoad - Preloaded app placement
appStore - App Store placement
channel - Channel on a partner device that launches the app or content within the app
continueWatching - Continue Watching content row
contractFixed - Placement that is contractually fixed, typically above the fold
hero - Deeplink generated from a Hero placement/banner on partner UI
keywordSearch - Deeplink generated from a Keyword Search and suggested results within a partner UI
marketingStripe - Marketing banner promoting content or the app within a partner UI
personalized - Personalized content row
promotional - Promotional placement
recentlyWatched - Personalized row that displays content the user has previously watched
recsAlgoDisney - Deeplinks that originate when users discover content from recommendations programmatically created by Disney
recsAlgoPartner - Deeplinks that originate when users discover content from recommendations programmatically created by the Partner
recsEditorialDisney - Deeplinks that originate when users discover content from recommendations based on editorial decisions by Disney
recsEditorialPartner - Deeplinks that originate when users discover content from recommendations based on editorial
decisions by the Partner
voiceSearch - Deeplink generated from a Voice Search and suggested results within a partner UI
Platform Identifier - Unique to each client team. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
Play mode identifier for Nintendo Switch.
An object containing additional information about a playback error presented to the user.

<- The reason for ending playback. applicationExit, when the application was terminated during playback. applicationBackground, when the application was sent to background during playback. Note if playback continues in PiP, it is not considered to have ended. user, when the user exits the player. error, when a fatal error occurs which prevents playback from continuing. playedToEnd, when the media plays to completion and the player automatically closes.

The intent which started playback.

autoplay, when the application automatically plays a video. e.g. the frontmost cell of a content carousel.

userAction, when the user clicks or taps on a video to begin playback.

autoAdvance, when a new media item automatically plays after the previous has ended. e.g. when viewing a series season or playlist.

background, when video is part of a UI element, such as a hero on a series detail page. pip, when the user explicitly enables picture in picture, or when implicitly enabled via backgrounding the app.

transferred, when the user transferres the video to Chromecast or Airplay.

tileFocus, when the user moves focus to a tile to begin playback, such as animated brand tiles feedSwitch,  indicate that that a user has switched between feeds in live content.

autoplayBrowseBackground, when video is auto played in the immersive video header in browse

useractionBrowseTileFocus, when the user does a live look-in on a tile in browse

<- Reason playback paused user, if the user pressed pause. stall, if the player paused due to insufficient buffer. applicationBackground, when the application was sent to background during playback. Note if playback continues in PiP, it is not considered backgrounded.

<- Reason playback resumed user, if the user pressed play from a paused state. stall, if the player buffered enough to resume playback. applicationForegrounded, where the application is brought to foreground after being previously background.
One of the pre-definied PBSes.

<- Reason playback seeked. app when the player jumps to live or the application decides the target playhead. skip when the user skips to a milestone (intro skip, recap end, or +/- x second skips). seek when the user seeks to a specific point by tapping on the timeline or dragging the playhead to a new position on the timeline. scrub when a new position is reached via linear reverse or forward playback at a non-1x rate.
Client generated ID of the stream/playback session
Client generated ID of the stream/playback session.
Time in milliseconds that it takes from intent-to-play to first frame rendered.

For media served by PBO v6 and below, the playbackUrl represents the url before the playback scenario has been injected.
For media served by PBO v7 and above, the playbackUrl represents one of the following:
- A base64 encoded resourceId, representing content returned from the Explore API.
- A base64 encoded mediaId which is a JSON object formatted as { "mediaId": value }, representing content returned from the Content API.

The location of the current content playhead, measured as a millisecond offset from the start time of content.

If value is not available, or is being reported for a sliding playlist, return -1.
Value of the playhead PROGRAM-DATE-TIME in epoch millis. Used to support calculation of offset from live.

average or peak (average is default). If known, we should indicate whether this is the average (e.g. `AVERAGE-BANDWIDTH`) or peak (e.g. `BANDWIDTH`) Alternatively, could apply logic on the backend to disambiguate based on known player behavior.

Product type, Live or VOD. Product type comes in the playlist response, but the SDK controls the serialization for this specific field. It is received from MediaApi.initializePlaybackContext() and used instead of the playlist response's value so the field can be supplied on all playback startup events.
Platform name as provided from Playlist Service QoS Data Object

Represents the path the channel was launched from.
homescreen, launched from the "home" section of the main Roku channel selection page
ad, launched from an ad displayed to the right of the channels on the home page
external-ontrol, launched via the ECP protocol. Typically this is from the Roku mobile app.
partner-button, launched via a partner button on the Roku remote
other-channel, launched from another channel on the Roku
auto-run-dev, launched as a sideloaded developer channel
debug-server, launched via the debug server on port 8080.
purchase-dialog, launched via the purchase dialog in our channel store
meta-search, launched from Roku Search
dial, launched via the DIAL protocol
Request-Id header. Header name as key, value as value. `null` value if expected but missing.

The number of milliseconds it took to receive a response from the backend service. The timer starts with user intent and ends when a response from the backend service is received but before rendering.
The elapsed time, in milliseconds, between sending the request and receiving the response. `null` if no response.
The SDK Platform as defined here : https://wiki.disneystreaming.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=SDKC&title=SDK+Platform+Values+Reporting+Documentation
The SDK platform
The version of the DSS SDK as used in the application integrated on the device
Search term in a given search. Used only when user initiates a search activity in the UI.
To indicate that the user is seeking to/from a specific point of playback eg. live playback (live edge).
Indication that the user is seeking by a fixed time (size) e.g. +30, -30
Value of the PROGRAM-DATE-TIME of the last (most recent) seekable segment + segment length in epoch millis i.e. end of last segment. Used to support live latency calculation.

Identifier that captures lifecycle of incarnations of the same page after partial reload (e.g. leave the page and hit back button, some sets are reloaded, others are taken from cache). The sequence will be incremented with every glimpse event sent. And included in search requests as well.
Id of the series that the content is in

The group IDs of the current playback session when using a certain backend QoS algorithm. This is for AB tests to optimize and tune QTEs backend QoS algorithms, like initial CDN selection, low profile usage, etc. Clients can get the value of this field from the payload responses at the beginning of each playback session. This field is a pass-through from the Playlist Service response, so SDK does not control the name or value.
The IP of the server. `null` if error.
Data about a request/response to a server.
The error code from the service or SDK.
The description of the error that occured from the BAMSDK, if available.
The SKU the user was attempting to purchase.

Where the error originated from, the intent is to identify the team that can likely take ownership of the error.
sdk errors are ones rooted in the sdk (i.e. JSON serialization errors, misuse of the SDK)
app errors come directly from the client and are present in the app itself (i.e. incorrect email format used for log in)
service errors are ones coming from back end service errors (i.e. unknown email used for log in).

The selected stream URL from the MediaPayload. If no stream URL is available, the default value should be the string "null".

Subscription unique identifier. This is an aggregation of the source fields as this is the main way some clients interact with the service. The format is $(source.type):$(source.provider):$(source.ref). For example: D2C:BAMTECH:urn:dss:launchpad:orders:eb1d3b95-aebc-47f8-a0e1-429de75b726b

Client Engineering Note: All subscription states provide a subscriptionId. These states include Active, Grace, Hold, Cancelled, Paused, and Churned. The states that are "entitled" are Active, Grace, and Cancelled. Entitled subscriptions provide full access to the app and video playback. When collecting the subscriptionId, look for the entitled subscription states in the order provided above.
This field is used to denote if a purchase is new purchase or an upgrade or a downgrade

A device identifier provided by the connected device operating system that initiated the license plate flow. Each operating system may provide one or more identifiers. Apple's iOS, for example, provides a vendor identifier and an advertising identifier.

/md
UUID representing a single element interaction within the container. The interactionId will correspond with one of the
above interactionTypes. The interactionId will be used as the primary key for all interactions.
[Reference FEDSA docs for UUID creation.](https://github.bamtech.co/pages/fed-solutions/documentation/data/glimpse/faq/#glimpse-faq)

The view that the launch event successfully ends on, which is the first fully rendered view that is ready for user interaction.

Note: Clients should now use the `pageViewId` value of the view as well as set the `launchDestinationType` enum field to `pageViewId` when the first fully rendered view is a page powered by Explore API; otherwise it should remain as `pageView`.
Enum describing the type of value provided in launchDestination.

Method by which the user enters the app:
  - main: Selected the app via the main menu of the operating system (or other default method per platform standards)
  - deepLink: Processed a deep link, either an app-specific URI or a universal link
  - rcu: Pressed an app-specific hardware button on a remote control unit
Metadata relevant to an app launch sequence. This data is most relevant upon completion as it may be unattainable prior to completion.

The stage of the app launch event within the launch sequence:
- launched: App launch sequence begins (initialization of the Disney "app runner" in which Disney code starts running). This occurs once and is always the first event in a launch sequence.
- backgroundInitialized: App has begun initialization in the background. Platforms with the capability to detect OS-initiated background launches should send this immediately after launched. Never sent for user-initiated launches.
- active: App is brought to the foreground by the user during the launch sequence. Sent immediately after launched for user-initiated launches. May be deferred for a long time after backgroundInitialized for OS-initiated background launches.
- exited: App is sent to the background by the user during the launch sequence prior to completion. This can optionally occur one or more times after a launched event and indicates failure when it is the final event in a launch sequence
- closed: App is explicitly terminated by the user or system. Event may not be reportable on all platforms.
- failed: App experiences an unrecoverable error (either a crash or a user-perceptible error) during the launch sequence. Event may not be reportable on all platforms (e.g., crash reporting is intercepted and handled by a separate process). This can optionally occur once after a launched event and is always the final event in a launch sequence when present.
- completed: App launch sequence ends successfully (the first fully rendered view that is ready for user interaction has been presented). This can optionally occur once after a launched event and is always the final event in a launch sequence when present.
OfferId represents a UUID that provides information on an offer presented to a user.
The Column number in the MatrixLocation field
The Row number in the MatrixLocation field

A string that identifies the third-party store corresponding to the purchase or identifies if the purchase was related to direct billing. Possible values are apple_store, google_play, amazon, roku, and direct_billing See transactionDetail description for explicit examples.

A string that identifies the user's current state within the purchase flow. purchasePartnerCompleted - Generated after the purchase has been completed with the third-party store (e.g. Apple, Google, etc.) but before activation
  or when the purchase has been completed with DSS commerce services (for direct billing).
tdaGranted - Generated if temporary default access (TDA) is granted to a user, separate from activation (for Direct Billing platforms ONLY) activationCompleted - Generated after a successful response from the activation service. activationTDAGranted - Generated if activation grants temporary default access (TDA) (for IAP platforms ONLY).

Transaction related data. This object will provide information about the purchase parter, the type of transaction identifier used (varies by 3rd party partner) and the actual value of the transaction identifier. -- Example Format -- e.g. { transactionId: "aaa-bbb", transactionIdType: "transactionIdentifier", purchasePartner: "apple_store"} e.g. { transactionId: "ccc-ddd", transactionIdType: "orderId", purchasePartner: "google_play"} e.g. { transactionId: "eee-fff", transactionIdType: "receiptId", purchasePartner: "amazon"} e.g. { transactionId: "ggg-hhh", transactionIdType: "purchaseId", purchasePartner: "roku"} e.g. { transactionId: "iii-jjj", transactionIdType: "guid", purchasePartner: "direct_billing"}

A string that uniquely identifies a successful payment transaction from either a third-party store or direct billing. For apple_store, use the `transactionIdentifier`. https://developer.apple.com/documentation/storekit/skpaymenttransaction/1411288-transactionidentifier. For google_play, use the purchase `orderId`. https://developers.google.com/android-publisher/api-ref/purchases/products. For amazon, use the `receiptId`. https://developer.amazon.com/docs/in-app-purchasing/iap-rvs-for-android-apps.html#rvs-request-syntax. For roku, use the `purchaseId`. For direct_billing, use the `guid` from the `orderId`. (ex. `orderId`: urn:dss:disney:orders:0c2b5299-d4ed-4f91-958c-a267368c18d7, `guid`: 0c2b5299-d4ed-4f91-958c-a267368c18d7)

A string that identifies the type of the ID corresponding to the transactionId. This can vary by third-party store or direct billing. Possible values are transactionIdentifier, orderId, receiptId, purchaseId, and guid See transactionDetail description for explicit examples.

A list of the serialized query string parameters to include in the request.

Each element in the list is a query string key value pair
that starts with the query string parameter name optionally
followed by "=", optionally followed by the query string
parameter value. For example, "foo=bar", "foo=", and "foo"
are all valid values. The query string parameter name and
the value MUST appear in the format in which it is expected
to be sent over the wire; if a key or value needs to be
percent-encoded, then it MUST appear percent-encoded in this list.

or scheme (for example, "example.com").

The host / endpoint that the client should send to, not including
the path or scheme (for example, "prefix.example.com").

This can differ from the host provided to the client if the `hostPrefix`
member of the `endpoint` trait is set, for instance.

The optional authentication scheme shape ID to assume. It's
possible that specific authentication schemes might influence
the serialization logic of an HTTP request.

A list of the expected serialized query string parameters.

Each element in the list is a query string key value pair
that starts with the query string parameter name optionally
followed by "=", optionally followed by the query string
parameter value. For example, "foo=bar", "foo=", and "foo"
are all valid values. The query string parameter name and
the value MUST appear in the format in which it is expected
to be sent over the wire; if a key or value needs to be
percent-encoded, then it MUST appear percent-encoded in this list.

A serialized HTTP request is not in compliance with the protocol
if any query string parameter defined in `queryParams` is not
defined in the request or if the value of a query string parameter
in the request differs from the expected value.

`queryParams` applies no constraints on additional query parameters.

A list of query string parameter names that must not appear in the
serialized HTTP request.

Each value MUST appear in the format in which it is sent over the
wire; if a key needs to be percent-encoded, then it MUST appear
percent-encoded in this list.

A list of query string parameter names that MUST appear in the
serialized request URI, but no assertion is made on the value.

Each value MUST appear in the format in which it is sent over the
wire; if a key needs to be percent-encoded, then it MUST appear
percent-encoded in this list.

Defines a map of expected HTTP headers.

Headers that are not listed in this map are ignored unless they are
explicitly forbidden through `forbidHeaders`.

A list of header field names that must not appear in the serialized
HTTP request.

A list of header field names that must appear in the serialized
HTTP message, but no assertion is made on the value.

Headers listed in `headers` do not need to appear in this list.

The expected HTTP message body.

If no request body is defined, then no assertions are made about
the body of the message.

The media type of the `body`.

This is used to help test runners to parse and validate the expected
data against generated data.

Defines the input parameters used to generated the HTTP request.

These parameters MUST be compatible with the input of the operation.

Defines vendor-specific parameters that are used to influence the
request. For example, some vendors might utilize environment
variables, configuration files on disk, or other means to influence
the serialization formats used by clients or servers.

If a `vendorParamsShape` is set, these parameters MUST be compatible
with that shape's definition.

A shape to be used to validate the `vendorParams` member contents.

If set, the parameters in `vendorParams` MUST be compatible with this
shape's definition.
A description of the test and what is being asserted.
Applies a list of tags to the test.

Indicates that the test case is only to be implemented by "client" or
"server" implementations. This property is useful for identifying and
testing edge cases of clients and servers that are impossible or
undesirable to test in *both* client and server implementations.

The identifier of the test case. This identifier can be used by
protocol test implementations to filter out unsupported test
cases by ID, to generate test case names, etc. The provided `id`
MUST match Smithy's `identifier` ABNF. No two `httpResponseTests`
test cases can share the same ID.
The shape ID of the protocol to test.
Defines the HTTP response code.

The optional authentication scheme shape ID to assume. It's possible
that specific authentication schemes might influence the serialization
logic of an HTTP response.

A map of expected HTTP headers. Each key represents a header field
name and each value represents the expected header value. An HTTP
response is not in compliance with the protocol if any listed header
is missing from the serialized response or if the expected header
value differs from the serialized response value.

`headers` applies no constraints on additional headers.
A list of header field names that must not appear.

A list of header field names that must appear in the serialized
HTTP message, but no assertion is made on the value.

Headers listed in `headers` map do not need to appear in this list.

Defines the HTTP message body.

If no response body is defined, then no assertions are made about
the body of the message.

The media type of the `body`.

This is used to help test runners to parse and validate the expected
data against generated data. Binary media type formats require that
the contents of `body` are base64 encoded.

Defines the output parameters deserialized from the HTTP response.

These parameters MUST be compatible with the output of the operation.

Defines vendor-specific parameters that are used to influence the
response. For example, some vendors might utilize environment
variables, configuration files on disk, or other means to influence
the serialization formats used by clients or servers.

If a `vendorParamsShape` is set, these parameters MUST be compatible
with that shape's definition.

A shape to be used to validate the `vendorParams` member contents.

If set, the parameters in `vendorParams` MUST be compatible with this
shape's definition.
A description of the test and what is being asserted.
Applies a list of tags to the test.

Indicates that the test case is only to be implemented by "client" or
"server" implementations. This property is useful for identifying and
testing edge cases of clients and servers that are impossible or
undesirable to test in *both* client and server implementations.
Define how a malformed HTTP request is rejected by a server given a specific protocol

Define how an HTTP request is serialized given a specific protocol,
authentication scheme, and set of input parameters.

Define how an HTTP response is serialized given a specific protocol,
authentication scheme, and set of output or error parameters.
The state the acceptor transitions to when matched.
The matcher used to test if the resource is in a given state.
Represents an acceptor in a waiter's state machine.

The waiter successfully finished waiting. This is a terminal
state that causes the waiter to stop.

The waiter failed to enter into the desired state. This is a
terminal state that causes the waiter to stop.

The waiter will retry the operation. This state transition is
implicit if no accepter causes a state transition.
The transition state of a waiter.

Matches on the successful output of an operation using a
JMESPath expression.

Matches on both the input and output of an operation using a JMESPath
expression. Input parameters are available through the top-level
`input` field, and output data is available through the top-level
`output` field. This matcher can only be used on operations that
define both input and output. This matcher is checked only if an
operation completes successfully.

Matches if an operation returns an error and the error matches
the expected error type. If an absolute shape ID is provided, the
error is matched exactly on the shape ID. A shape name can be
provided to match an error in any namespace with the given name.

When set to `true`, matches when an operation returns a successful
response. When set to `false`, matches when an operation fails with
any error.

Defines how an acceptor determines if it matches the current state of
a resource.
Matches if the return value is a string that is equal to the expected string.
Matches if the return value is a boolean that is equal to the string literal 'true' or 'false'.
Matches if all values in the list matches the expected string.
Matches if any value in the list matches the expected string.
Defines a comparison to perform in a PathMatcher.
A JMESPath expression applied to the input or output of an operation.
The expected return value of the expression.

The comparator used to compare the result of the expression with the
expected value.

Defines how to test the result of a JMESPath expression against
an expected value.
Documentation about the waiter. Can use CommonMark.
An ordered array of acceptors to check after executing an operation.

The minimum amount of time in seconds to delay between each retry.
This value defaults to 2 if not specified. If specified, this value
MUST be greater than or equal to 1 and less than or equal to
`maxDelay`.

The maximum amount of time in seconds to delay between each retry.
This value defaults to 120 if not specified (or, 2 minutes). If
specified, this value MUST be greater than or equal to 1.

Indicates if the waiter is considered deprecated. A waiter SHOULD
be marked as deprecated if it has been replaced by another waiter or
if it is no longer needed (for example, if a resource changes from
eventually consistent to strongly consistent).

A list of tags associated with the waiter that allow waiters to be
categorized and grouped.
Defines an individual operation waiter.

Indicates that an operation has various named "waiters" that can be used
to poll a resource until it enters a desired state.
